slides.title: What is Genetics?
slides.content:
# The Instructions üìú

Genetics is the study of heredity and the variation of inherited characteristics.

- **Gene**: A segment of DNA that codes for a protein.
- **Genome**: An organism's complete set of DNA.

slides.title: DNA Structure
slides.content:
# The Double Helix üß¨

Deoxyribonucleic Acid.
- Discovered by Watson, Crick, and Franklin.
- Sugar-Phosphate backbone.
- 4 Nitrogen Bases: **A**denine, **T**hymine, **C**ytosine, **G**uanine.

Pairing Rule: **A pairs with T**, **C pairs with G**.

slides.title: DNA Replication
slides.content:
# Copying the Code üì†

Before cell division, DNA must copy itself.
- Helicase unzips the helix.
- DNA Polymerase adds new bases.
- Result: Two identical strands (Semi-conservative: half old, half new).

slides.title: RNA vs DNA
slides.content:
# The Messenger üì®

RNA (Ribonucleic Acid):
- Single stranded.
- Sugar is Ribose.
- Has **Uracil (U)** instead of Thymine (T).

Roles: mRNA (messenger), tRNA (transfer), rRNA (ribosomal).

slides.title: Central Dogma
slides.content:
# Flow of Info ‚û°Ô∏è

**DNA $\to$ RNA $\to$ Protein**

1. **Transcription**: DNA copied to mRNA in nucleus.
2. **Translation**: mRNA read by ribosome to build protein in cytoplasm.

slides.title: Mendelian Genetics
slides.content:
# Gregor Mendel ü´õ

The Father of Genetics (studied pea plants).

- **Allele**: Variant form of a gene (e.g., Purple or White flower).
- **Dominant**: Masks recessive (Capital letter, P).
- **Recessive**: Hidden if dominant is present (Lowercase, p).

slides.title: Genotype vs Phenotype
slides.content:
# Inside vs Outside üé≠

- **Genotype**: The genetic makeup.
  - *Homozygous Dominant (PP)*
  - *Heterozygous (Pp)*
  - *Homozygous Recessive (pp)*

- **Phenotype**: The physical appearance (Purple or White).

slides.title: Punnett Squares
slides.content:
# Predicting Kids üë∂

A grid used to predict offspring genotypes.

Example: Pp x Pp
- 25% PP
- 50% Pp
- 25% pp

Ratio: 3 Purple : 1 White.

slides.title: Non-Mendelian Genetics
slides.content:
# Usually it's Complicated üòµ‚Äçüí´

- **Incomplete Dominance**: Blending (Red + White = Pink).
- **Codominance**: Both show up (Spots).
- **Multiple Alleles**: Blood types (A, B, O).
- **Polygenic**: Many genes for one trait (Height, Skin color).

slides.title: Sex-Linked Traits
slides.content:
# X and Y üöª

Genes on sex chromosomes.
- Females: XX, Males: XY.
- Males are more affected by X-linked recessive traits (Color blindness, Hemophilia) because they only have one X.

slides.title: Mutations
slides.content:
# Mistakes Happen ‚ö†Ô∏è

Changes in DNA sequence.
- **Point Mutation**: Single base change.
- **Frameshift**: Insertion/Deletion shifts everything (Major damage!).
- Causes: UV, Radiation, Chemicals, Random errors.

slides.title: Genetic Disorders
slides.content:
# When Genes Break üè•

- **Down Syndrome**: Extra chromosome 21 (Trisomy).
- **Cystic Fibrosis**: Recessive gene defect.
- **Huntington's**: Dominant lethal gene.
- **Sickle Cell**: Point mutation affecting hemoglobin.

slides.title: Biotechnology
slides.content:
# Hacking Life üíª

Using biology for technology.
- **PCR**: Copying DNA rapidly.
- **Gel Electrophoresis**: Separating DNA (CSI style).
- **Cloning**: Dolly the sheep.

slides.title: GMOs
slides.content:
# Modified Food üåΩ

Genetically Modified Organisms.
- Inserting genes (e.g., bacteria gene into corn to kill bugs).
- Pros: Higher yield, nutrition, pest resistance.
- Cons: Unknown ecosystem effects, patenting life.

slides.title: CRISPR-Cas9
slides.content:
# Gene Editing ‚úÇÔ∏è

Revolutionary tool to cut and paste DNA precisely.
- Potential to cure genetic diseases.
- Ethical concerns: "Designer Babies"?

slides.title: Epigenetics
slides.content:
# Above Genetics üëª

Chemical markers on top of DNA can turn genes on or off without changing the sequence.
- Environment (Diet, Stress) affects these markers.
- You can pass these to your kids!

slides.title: Genetics Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **DNA** creates **RNA** which creates **Proteins**.
- **Alleles** determine traits (Mendel).
- **Mutations** drive variation and disease.
- **Modern Biotech** allows us to read and rewrite the code of life.
